current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act so as to eliminate the authority of the
			 Secretary of Health and Human Services to limit the ability of medical
			 providers to conduct lawful business, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Safeguarding Care Of Patients
			 Everywhere Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Safeguarding Care Of Patients Everywhere Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The practice of
			 medicine is guided by a set of principles contained in the Hippocratic
			 oath,
			 which in part directs medical practitioners to “remember that I do not
			 treat a
			 fever chart, a cancerous growth, but a sick human being”.

Historically, the
			 practice of medicine has been principally governed by the laws of each of
			 the
			 50 States, not the Federal Government.

State medical
			 licensing and disciplinary boards administer medical practice laws and
			 have the
			 principal responsibility to protect the public from improper and unlawful
			 medical practices.

Such boards define
			 activities that constitute the legitimate practice of medicine.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
are not governed by the Hippocratic oath or a medical board
			 of
			 any of the 50 States.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Secretary of Health and
			 Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: are not determined solely by the needs of patients.

text.#text:
Individual and institutional financial
			 interests can influence the discretion and actions of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Patient Protection and Affordable Care
			 Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1311/ss:h

text.#text:
make findings
			 regarding the quality of medical care and the activities that constitute
			 the
			 legitimate practice of medicine; and

on the basis of these findings, terminate
			 or limit the ability of medical providers to conduct lawful business, thus
			 restricting the practice of medicine by curtailing economic activity.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
such improper authority, which presents a threat to the
			 health
			 and welfare of patients in the United States.

text.#text:
The purpose of this Act is to remove from
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
			 relating to the authority of the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1311/ss:h

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to
			 regulate contracts between qualified health plans and health care
			 providers
			 based on findings of health care quality.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

Section 1311 of the Patient Protection and
			 Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1311

header.#text:
Repeal of
			 restrictions on the professional practice of physicians and other health
			 care
			 providers entering into contracts with health plans
